Alternatively, students will be UTSC undergraduates in the third or fourth year of their program, and have received excellent grades in the following courses.  MGTA05H3 (or MGTA01 and MGTA02), MGAB01h3, MGAB02H3, MGFB10H3, MGFC10H3, MGMA01H3, MGMB01H3, MGSB22H3.
qualifications_preferred:
Preference will be given to a graduate student with an undergraduate degree in business, and pursuing their graduate degree in marketing, accounting, finance or an MBA.
Alternatively, students will be UTSC undergraduates in the third or fourth year of their program, and have received excellent grades in the following courses.  MGTA05H3 (or MGTA01 and MGTA02), MGAB01h3, MGAB02H3, MGFB10H3, MGFC10H3, MGMA01H3, MGMB01H3, MGSB22H3.

duties:
Respond to student questions and concerns by e-mail, in lieu of on-campus office hours.

Grade 2 or 3 in-semester quizzes and short tests, using Quercus Speedgrader, and input grades to Quercus Gradecentre.and/or Excel spreadsheets

Respond to student questions and concerns regarding the grading of in-semester tests.

Grade the final examination, using Quercus Speedgrader, and input grades to Quercus Gradecentre.and/or Excel spreadsheets

TAs are expected to be available by e-mail and by virtual collaborations software, to meet throughout the term with students, the First year Program Advisor, and the Faculty member teaching the course.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Enrolment as a graduate student or undergraduate student. 

Graduate applicants must have an MBA, BBA, B. Com or an equivalent undergraduate degree with grades of A or better in undergraduate courses equivalent to MGTA01 or MGTA05H3.

Undergraduate applicants must have scored A or better in MGTA01H3 or MGTA05H3, and have a CGA of 3.5 or higher.  

Applicants must have mastered the course material and be able to answer student questions related to the course content.

Applicants must have outstanding English language communication abilities (both oral and written) and have the ability to provide written feedback to submitted work.
qualifications_preferred:
Enrolment as a graduate student or undergraduate student. 

Graduate applicants must have an MBA, BBA, B. Com or an equivalent undergraduate degree with grades of A or better in undergraduate courses equivalent to MGTA01 or MGTA05H3.

Undergraduate applicants must have scored A or better in MGTA01H3 or MGTA05H3, and have a CGA of 3.5 or higher.  

Applicants must have mastered the course material and be able to answer student questions related to the course content.

Applicants must have outstanding English language communication abilities (both oral and written) and have the ability to provide written feedback to submitted work.

duties:
Holding pre- and post-midterm office hours to advise and counsel students, and explain test marking. Holding pre-exam office hours to advise and counsel students.  Marking mid-term tests and final examinations. Invigilating the mid-term test and the final examination. 

TAs are expected to be available at UTSC on a regular basis throughout the term to meet with students and the professors teaching the course.

All duties must be completed at UTSC or online.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Enrolment as a graduate student or undergraduate student. Graduate applicants must have an MBA, BBA,  B.Com or equivalent degree.  Undergraduates must have completed MGTA01 and MGTA02 (or MGTA05).  Completion of MGAB01 and MGMA01 are desirable, with grades of A or better in these courses. Applicants should have a CGPA of 3.5 or higher.  TAs must have mastered the material in the introductory management courses, as well introductory financial accounting, and the principles of marketing. TAs must be able to answer student questions, explain all theories and concepts in the syllabus, and provide advice and guidance on course materials, test and exam preparation.
qualifications_preferred: Enrolment as a graduate student or undergraduate student. Graduate applicants must have an MBA, BBA,  B.Com or equivalent degree.  Undergraduates must have completed MGTA01 and MGTA02 (or MGTA05).  Completion of MGAB01 and MGMA01 are desirable, with grades of A or better in these courses. Applicants should have a CGPA of 3.5 or higher.  TAs must have mastered the material in the introductory management courses, as well introductory financial accounting, and the principles of marketing. TAs must be able to answer student questions, explain all theories and concepts in the syllabus, and provide advice and guidance on course materials, test and exam preparation.

duties: In addition, TAs will be required to attend classes to assist in organizing class presentations and providing feedback to students regarding assignments. TAs will conduct weekly tutorials.  TAs will also assist in invigilating and grading tests.  All duties are to be completed at UTSC.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Enrolment as a graduate or undergraduate student who has successfully completed MGTA36H3/MGTA35H3 (or equivalent) with an excellent grade.  Must possess exceptional oral communication skills, experience in working with and motivating small groups.  TAs will be required to use technology to record, post and grade oral presentations of the students in the course, thus competence around such technology is an asset.
qualifications_preferred: Enrolment as a graduate or undergraduate student who has successfully completed MGTA36H3/MGTA35H3 (or equivalent) with an excellent grade.  Must possess exceptional oral communication skills, experience in working with and motivating small groups.  TAs will be required to use technology to record, post and grade oral presentations of the students in the course, thus competence around such technology is an asset.

job_title: Teaching French as a Second Language
duties: All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a university credit course, including preparation and delivery of course content; development, administration and marking of assignments; calculation and submission of grades; holding regular office hours. Coordinating experiential learning placements in educational settings; collecting and processing vulnerable sector police record checks and other required documents.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Ph. D. in progress in Education or related field, specializing in French language education. Native or near-native proficiency in French and experience teaching French as a second language. Sound knowledge and understanding of the subject matter gained through previous involvement with the course or its equivalents. Strong academic record and professional promise.
qualifications_preferred: Previous training and experience in teaching and learning, and second-language pedagogy. Previous involvement and familiarity with the department’s French language and education curriculum. Experience with supervising experiential learning placements and reflective assignments.

duties: Must be able to be physically present regularly (2 days a week at minimum!) on the UTM campus to lead weekly labs/tutorials, office hours, meetings with the instructor, etc. Applicants must explicitly indicate their in-person availability, not remote availability in the application system. Applicants who do not meet these availability requirements will not be considered. Most positions will require TAs to be able to commute regularly to the UTM campus to lead weekly labs. Other duties include office hours, marking assignments, tests and exams, holding office hours, and answering student questions on Piazza. Labs will be graded weekly, so there is an expectation to be able to turn around ~3 hours of grading in ~5 days on a weekly basis.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Good understanding of basic Machine Learning methods (e.g., cross-validation, linear regression, logistic regression, decision trees, naive Bayes, gradient descent, neural nets, mixture of Gaussians, ensemble methods, PCA, reinforcement learning). Good knowledge of calculus, linear algebra and basic probability. Programming experience with Python, Numpy and scikit-learn. Expertise with the CSC311 content, and beyond. Strong grades in a minimum of 3.0 FCEs of CSC courses from UTM, including at least 1.0 FCEs of machine learning courses. Note that CSC-like courses offered in different departments do not count towards the FCE requirement as the courses offered in other departments or in other campuses differ widely in content, coverage, or expectations.
Must be familiar with this course offering from UTM and the UTM compute infrastructure. Strong organizational skills and strong written/spoken English communication skills, including a demonstrated and consistent ability to complete work on time and with a high level of attention to detail.

application_procedure: Applicants should submit a cover letter including the names of two references (preferably academic), examples of teaching evaluations (if available), and CV to the UC TA Online application site at: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/uc/login  by Thursday 6 November 2025. If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact Khamla Sengthavy at Khamla.sengthavy@utoronto.ca or 416-978-8083.
duties: Meeting with instructors, attending online tutorials, responding to student inquiries and marking assignments.  The position may also include attending some lectures. Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: At a minimum, a relevant bachelor’s degree.
qualifications_preferred: Relevant academic background in public health, health care, or health policy an asset. First consideration will be given to full-time graduate students at the University of Toronto.
salery: $53.92/hour plus 4% vacation pay (UG, SGSI, SGSII, PDF)

application_procedure: Send a cover letter and CV addressed to the selection committee by e-mail in a PDF format to: cpssljobs.utm@utoronto.ca.
duties: All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a university credit course, including but not limited to preparation and delivery of course content, development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and examinations, calculations and submission of grades, provide direction and supervision of TA's, and holding regular office hours.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: In progress Ph.D. in relevant area of Earth Science
qualifications_preferred: Completed Ph.D. in relevant area of Earth Science
salery: In accordance with the current CUPE3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement, the Course Instructor rate of pay will be $9,442.98 excludes vacation pay for a half course.
ta_support: TA support provided to run PRA's and some marking suppot
tutorial: For the most up-to-date course timetable and delivery methods, please visit UTM timetable planner: https://ttb.utoronto.ca/.

application_procedure:
Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. The deadline to submit your application is October 22, 2025. For more information, you may contact:
Angela Niazmand
Undergraduate and TA Administrator
Department of Statistical Sciences
University of Toronto
700 University Avenue
Ontario Power Building - 9160-6
Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5
www.statistics.utoronto.ca
E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:
Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
o	Must demonstrate to have successfully completed a senior undergraduate course in regression analysis covering course topics or equivalent
o	Experience performing statistical analyses in R + R-Studio
qualifications_preferred:
o	Experience in report writing and statistical communication
o	Experience providing written and formative feedback to others or a demonstrated interest to develop such skills
o	Familiarity with scientific report structure and best practices
o	Experience answering variety of student questions (e.g. debugging code, writing advice, writing proofs and problem solving, data analysis techniques)
o	Experience working with survey design, collection, or analysis

duties: Will include some of the following: running tutorials, marking, invigilation, office hours, preparatory work, and other duties of administering the course.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Strong grades in a minimum of 3.0 FCEs of mathematics courses, including at least 1.0 FCEs of primarily proof-based courses. Note that "MAT-like" courses offered in different departments do not count towards the FCE requirement as they do not adhere to the standards of rigour used in mathematics courses. In the alternative, applicants whose portfolio includes at least 2.0 FCEs of MAT specialist classes will be deemed to have satisfied the FCE requirement. The candidate must have strong grades and demonstrated knowledge of the course content and beyond; have a demonstrated record of commitment to teaching pedagogy and student learning; have a demonstrated record of timeliness in communication and carrying out duties; and possess excellent communication skills and professionalism.

job_title: Introduction to Canadian Environmental Law and Policy II
application_procedure: Please submit current Curriculum Vitae (including valid email address) with cover letter and a proposed course syllabus to: Steven Bernstein, Distinguished Professor and Chair jobs.politicalscienceutm@utoronto.ca.  Please include the course ID in the subject line.
duties: Preparation and delivery of course content; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams; calculation and submission of grades (including any grading or submission of grades not completed by the end of session), holding regular office hours; supervising TAs (if any) assigned to the course. NOTE: Mode of delivery of this course is IN PERSON.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: University of Toronto graduate students, in progress of a PhD in a relevant discipline or other relevant qualifications or professional experience. We are seeking previous experience in teaching, teaching excellence, and mastery of subject area.
qualifications_preferred: Previous experience teaching a similar course is highly desirable.

application_procedure: Please submit current Curriculum Vitae (including valid email address) with cover letter and a proposed course syllabus to: Steven Bernstein, Distinguished Professor and Chair jobs.politicalscienceutm@utoronto.ca.  Please include the course ID in the subject line.

application_procedure:
Please prepare a single PDF consisting of:  

(1) BME’s application form which can be download here: https://bme.utoronto.ca/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/2024_BME-TA-Application.docx
  
(2) An updated CV, and  

(3) If available, proof of WHMIS and safety training. Proof of completion of EHS training can be submitted by sending a screenshot of your EHS training record.  
 
Once prepared, please submit your application via 

https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/752 for LECTURE position,
https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/753 for TUTORIAL positions,
https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/754 for PRACTICAL positions, and
https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/755 for MARKING positions.
  
If you require assistance submitting your application, please contact: projects.bme@utoronto.ca.

job_title: Exploring Health and Society: Theories, Perspectives, and Patterns
application_procedure: All applications must be submitted to the Online Teaching Application at: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/slship/jobs.php
duties: Please note that classes will be held in person. All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a university credit course, including preparation and delivery of course content; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams; calculation and submission of grades; supervising TAs, holding regular office hours.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants should be an upper level doctoral student, post-doctoral fellow, or equivalent. Demonstrated ability to design a syllabus and course materials that reflect departmental guidelines and incorporate current scholarship in health studies. Proven experience teaching and facilitating discussion with undergraduate students in-person. Research area and academic training must be closely aligned with the themes of the course, including: Social, biological and environmental determinants of health. Biomedical culture and health care. Globalization and international health issues. Health technology and information systems. Fundamentals of epidemiology. Theories and analytical methodologies used in health studies and the social sciences
qualifications_preferred: Applicants should be an upper level doctoral student, post-doctoral fellow, or equivalent. Demonstrated ability to design a syllabus and course materials that reflect departmental guidelines and incorporate current scholarship in health studies. Globalization and international health issues. Health technology and information systems. Fundamentals of epidemiology. Theories and analytical methodologies used in health studies and the social sciences
salery: Winter 2026: UG/SGS1/SGS11 & PDFs $53.92 / $53.92 / $53.92 per hour plus 4% vacation pay

job_title: Navigating Health and Society: Research, Practice, and Policy
application_procedure: All applications must be submitted to the Online Teaching Application at: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/slship/jobs.php
duties: Please note that classes will be held in person. Must be able to attend classes and meetings at UTSC, as required. Preparation for classes; preparation of written or audio-visual materials; possibly attending lectures, teaching, and/or leading discussions; rating students' work; holding office hours; consulting with students (including electronic consultation); writing, grading and/or invigilation of tests/examinations; grading term papers and essays; communicating with course instructor and other TAs; other ad hoc tasks. The successful incumbent will also lead tutorials.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Graduate study in public health preferred. Knowledge of the following: broad determinants of health; health psychology; sociology of health/illness; health promotion; models of health care and health policy; health inequities at the local and global level. Ability to use Quercus and Excel are required. Previous experience evaluating writing, provision of constructive written feedback on assignments and scrupulous record-keeping are expected. High attention to detail, good track record and good time management skills. Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate study in public health preferred. Knowledge of the following: broad determinants of health; health psychology; sociology of health/illness; health promotion; models of health care and health policy; health inequities at the local and global level. Ability to use Quercus and Excel are required. Previous experience evaluating writing, provision of constructive written feedback on assignments and scrupulous record-keeping are expected. High attention to detail, good track record and good time management skills. Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
salery: Winter 2026: UG/SGS1/SGS11 & PDFs $53.92 / $53.92 / $53.92 per hour plus 4% vacation pay

department: Department of Mathematical and Computational Science
application_procedure: If interested, please reply to: jobsmcs.utm@utoronto.ca  with the following information by 06 November 2025: 1) your current CV, including a clear description of your teaching experience; 2) your current status; your department; your research area; 3) the name and e-mail address of at least one reference who can comment on your teaching ability (optional)
duties: Duties include: planning the lectures, assignments and tests and marking schemes; providing appropriate contact time outside of class to students through office hours, emails, etc.; invigilating the midterm and final exam; managing the grades and submitting the final course grades; handling student petitions; setting and grading a make-up exam if required. While there is a lot of room for creativity in course delivery, instructors will be expected to follow the basic content and style used by the faculty members who normally teach the course.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Enrollment in or completion of a graduate degree in Mathematics. Advanced comprehension of the subject matter as evidenced by research activity, industry experience, or teaching experience.Strong organizational, interpersonal, and communication skills.
qualifications_preferred: n/a
ta_support: 54 hours per 30 students enrolled per semester

job_title: Asia and the World in the 21st Century
department: Asian Institute at the Munk School of Global Affairs & Public Policy
application_procedure: Applicants should submit a cover letter and updated CV (including previous teaching evaluations if applicable) by October 31, 2025. Letters of recommendation are not required but will be accepted. Applications should be sent via email to Asian Institute Program Administrator and Communications Officer, Rebecca Bi at ai.asianstudies@utoronto.ca.  YOU MUST USE THE FOLLOWING FOR YOUR SUBJECT LINE: APPLICATION: COURSE CODE: LAST NAME. Please attach your CV and cover letter as PDFs, and label your attachments as follows: Last Name_First Name_Cover; Last Name_First Name_CV. The final number of hours is subject to enrolment changes.
duties:
Consultations with the instructor 
Mark assignments and tests 
Hold office hours for counselling students 

Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located. Where the duties are intended to be performed at another location, such other location will be specified in the posting.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Demonstrated interest in Asia-Pacific and/or South Asian Studies and strong performance in a social sciences or humanities graduate program is required.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to candidates with grounded research experience in East, Southeast, and/or South Asian Studies who are excelling in their respective disciplinary graduate program, and those that evince a multi-regional social science perspective that includes critical approaches to area studies, public culture and markets, ethnography and/or historical studies. First consideration will be given to senior PhD students at the University of Toronto, but strong MA students are invited to apply. TA experience is preferred.

duties:
“- Preparing and delivering the lectures in-person on campus as scheduled.
- Handling course administration including: maintaining the course website on quercus; developing marking schemes/syllabus; planning tutorial content (when applicable); developing course assessments including assignments, projects, quizzes, tests, and final assessments.
- Providing appropriate contact time outside of class to students, through office hours, email, the course website and/or the course bulletin board.
- Preparing the breakdown of hours for TA duties in the course and supervising the TAs.
- Ensuring that tutorials and/or labs are delivered appropriately by the TAs.
- Managing the grading for the course, which is largely done by the TAs, and carrying out any grading not handled by the TAs.
- Invigilating term tests and the final exam when applicable.
- Managing the grades, including the timely completion and release of grades and feedback to students throughout the term; submitting final course grades (due May 8, 2026).

While there is a lot of room for creativity in course delivery, instructors will be expected to follow the basic content and style used by the faculty members who normally teach the course, and must get approval from these faculty members or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate on any substantial changes to the course content or assessment methods. Instructors will also be expected to consult with the department's Teaching Support group when creating the course syllabus, final exam, and test(s).
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

- demonstrated expertise in topic area of the course
- strong organizational, interpersonal, and communication skills
- previous experience as a course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset
- demonstrated evidence of excellence in Teaching an asset

Expertise with applied statistics, including methods of visualizing and analyzing univariate, bivariate, and multivariate data.  Research experience is required, including knowledge of writing and reviewing research proposals; excellent communication skills; interest, enthusiasm, and experience in scientific research; available to students via email within 24 hours (excluding weekends) for duration of TAship.
qualifications_preferred: Candidates with previous research, forensic science background, teaching, and marking experience and are preferred.

qualifications_minimum: A Master’s degree in Biology or related forensic sub discipline field (in progress or completed), with an undergraduate Forensic Biology degree or substantial background in Forensic Biology or very closely related field with practical DNA lab experience.
qualifications_preferred: Professional designation and/or professional experience is an asset; demonstrated excellence in course subject matter; prior experience working in a forensic science lab setting is highly preferred, as is WHIMS training. Preference will be given to candidates with experience in the following: Laboratory Analysis of Forensic Biological Evidence and crime scene investigation; Forensic Serology & Basic Serology techniques, General experience in molecular biology methods & Forensic DNA profiling:  DNA extraction methods; DNA quantitation methods; PCR; SNP genotyping (Real Time PCR and Luminex); STR genotyping using capillary sequencer, primer design.

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
application_procedure: Please submit a Unit 1 Course Instructor Application Form, Resume and Teaching Dossier (merged into a single PDF file ) to the MIE Undergraduate Office by email at ugservices@mie.utoronto.ca no later than October 22, 2025 at 11:59PM (Eastern Time). The Course Instructor Application Form can be found on the MIE Careers page here: https://www.mie.utoronto.ca/faculty-staff/careers/. Applicants must include full contact information of their supervisor, plus two U of T employees (faculty or staff) who can testify to the teaching skills of the applicant.  The appointment will be made at the earliest possible time before the commencement of classes by the Associate Chair (Undergraduate) of the Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering.  No other offers or notices of the outcome of applications are authorized by the Department.  Final availability of the position is contingent upon final course determination, enrolment, budgetary considerations, and the final determination of assignments flowing from Article 14:03 of the Collective Agreement.

job_title: Statistics and Scientific Inquiry in the Life Sciences
application_procedure:
Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. The deadline to submit your application is November 3, 2025. For more information, you may contact:
Angela Niazmand
Undergraduate and TA Administrator
Department of Statistical Sciences
University of Toronto
700 University Avenue
Ontario Power Building - 9160-6
Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5
www.statistics.utoronto.ca
E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:
Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required:
o	Undergraduate degree with Statistics Minor or Major and current graduate student in Statistics, Biostatistics, or related discipline
o	Experience with quantitative life science research and/or analysis and interpretation of resulting data (e.g., coursework and/or research)
o	Experience performing statistical analyses using R/R Markdown and ability to troubleshoot technical issues
o	Available to attend class meetings in-person for both LEC sections to support students on weeks with scheduled class activities such as labs
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred: 
o	PhD candidate in Statistics, Biostatistics, or related discipline
o	Experience answering a variety of student questions (e.g., debugging code, writing advise, data analyses) or a demonstrated interest to develop such skill
o	Experience providing written and formative feedback to students or a demonstrated interest to develop such skill
o	Ability to communicate, both verbally and in writing, with a diverse team in a clear and precise manner
o	Ability to assist students search for and understand relevant literature
o	Familiarity with scientific report structure, scientific writing, and best practices
o	Previous TA experience and professional development in teaching (e.g., TATP workshops)
o	Previous experience with STA288H1: Statistics and Scientific Inquiry in the Life Sciences

Meeting Schedule: 	Lecture:	TH:11:00-13:00 (tentative)
			Tutorials:	N/A

application_procedure:
Apply here: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/dept/ctl/app/ta

To complete the application, please upload the following documents:
1. Cover Letter
2. Curriculum Vitae or Resume
3. Statement of Teaching Interest
4. A short writing sample (maximum 4 pages)
5. Contact information of THREE references.
6. Teaching evaluations (optional)
duties:
Teaching assistants will prepare motivating and stimulating materials that engage students in dynamic and interactive learning during practicums, provide constructive feedback and encourage confidence-building participation that develops students’ competence in academic oral and written communication. The special focus on rapid expansion of core vocabulary and academic writing provides the foundation and practical experience for students to cope effectively with university-level academic texts and assignment expectations. Students will engage actively in collaborative peer learning through consistent engagement with cell group interactions, Peer Scholar interactions, assigned group work outside class as well as through online learning.

Responsible for leading one in-person practicum session per week on Wednesdays, 12pm – 1 pm in a way that establishes a robust highly-interactive learning community in the physical class; conduct office hours; grade projects, assignments, oral presentations and reflective journals, mid-terms and final assessments; facilitate the discussion board to stimulate an active and genuine exchange of ideas and deepening of critical thinking skills; grade quality of participation in discussion board and Peer Scholar; responsible for conducting assessments in accordance with criteria specified and provide supportive written feedback and guidance that helps individual students to develop their vocabulary and increase their critical thinking and academic writing skills. Invigilation of the in-person mid-term test may be required.

Appointment Dates: January 5, 2026 - April 30, 2026 
Practicum Dates: January 14, 2026 to March 25, 2026
Practicum Times: Wednesdays, 12:00-1:00pm (In-person)
Office Hours: To be arranged

qualifications_minimum: A minimum Master’s degree in a relevant field; a minimum of 3 years of experience teaching at a university; evidence of ability to support the development of critical thinking and academic communication skills (especially academic writing) of multilingual university students who have significant needs related to English for Academic Purposes; relevant experience teaching writing one-on-one and/or teaching in university courses with a significant writing instruction component; demonstrated ability and high level of comfort discussing and teaching grammar to students in university courses; excellent communication and motivational skills, demonstrated ability to be perceived as highly approachable by students; and demonstrated ability to create a lively, highly motivating learning environment and sustain students’ interest in learning (as reflected through student attendance and engagement throughout the semester).
qualifications_preferred: Experience supporting student learning through an online environment; training in writing, education, or applied linguistics would be a great asset; experience working with a diverse group of students and training in second-language instruction at the university level; demonstrated evidence of active involvement in research in the field of second language writing; experience with teaching that involves critical Artificial Intelligence (AI) literacy with specified use of Generative AI in achieving course goals; a demonstrated ability and experience using Canvas (Quercus), and knowledge and experience using web conferencing tools such as Microsoft Teams and Zoom.

application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter, CV, and the contact information for two references in the same PDF to typ.office@utoronto.ca by October 14, 2025  at 5 PM.
duties:
NOTE: TA position is for the 2026 winter term period ONLY.
The Teaching Assistant will support the course instructor in the instruction and management of TYP014 (Introduction to University Studies), a core course of the Transitional Year Program at University of Toronto. This course aims to help students develop and strengthen the academic and life skills required to succeed as university students. It will include presentations on and practice in time management, note taking, study skills, essay writing, and preparation for examinations. In addition, it will deal with important matters for supporting mature students such as financial aid and how to get it, balancing study with family obligations, paid labour and other life contingencies, effective use of major student services, and techniques for dealing with the stresses and complications of academic life. The winter term section of the course will place greater emphasis on transitional supports for TYP students as they prepare to transfer into the Faculty of Arts and Science at the University of Toronto. We are therefore seeking someone with a strong understanding of these supports and the needs students may have during this transition. The Teaching Assistant (TA) will support the course instructor in the general instruction and management of the course. The TA will help to lead a classes that support TYP students in their development of academic and life skills, including note-taking, the writing process, research, organization, and other related skills. The TA will evaluate student work, provide feedback, schedule and hold office hours,  provide academic support for course assignments, and lead discussions, and manage the course Quercus. Additional duties will be determined in consultation with the course instructor and registrar. The TA will be required to attend  lectures, and occasional staff meetings. Please note, this course will be offered in person, with online elements (i.e. Quercus). For more information about TYP, please visit typ.utoronto.ca.

The candidate must demonstrate a commitment to equity and anti-oppressive/social-justice approaches to education and familiarity with Quercus and online instructional methods.
qualifications_preferred:
The candidate must have: (a) Previous work experience and/ or coursework relating to educational access, anti-oppression, and social-justice approaches to post-secondary education.                                          (b) In-depth knowledge of the University of Toronto community and student experience.                                         (c) Knowledge of/ or experience with adult education and the University of Toronto Transitional Year Program or similar programming. (d) Experience advising students and providing writing support in the social sciences and/ or humanities. 
Shortlisted candidates may be asked to complete a brief written screening question and/or an interview.

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
duties: Duties and Responsibilities • Conduct weekly laboratory and tutorial sessions to support lectures, with a focus on practical application of finite element analysis (FEA). • Revise and test all lab/tutorial questions, solutions, and FEA case studies prior to each session. • Provide hands-on assistance to students during lab and tutorial periods, guiding them through FEA software workflows, modeling approaches, and interpretation of results. • Ensure students clearly understand lab/tutorial requirements, safety protocols, and analysis procedures. • Grade quizzes, lab reports, midterm, and final exam components, and upload results to Quercus. • Assist in the invigilation of exams and maintain academic integrity standards. • Treat all students with respect, answer their questions clearly and concisely, and encourage active participation in labs/tutorials. • Support students in developing experimental validation approaches and critical thinking in FEA applications.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Required Qualifications: A degree in Mechanical, Aerospace, or Civil Engineering, or a closely related discipline. • Strong, demonstrated hands-on experience in finite element analysis (model setup, meshing, boundary conditions, post-processing) using commercial FEA software (e.g., ANSYS, Abaqus, COMSOL, or equivalent). • CAD modelling is an asset for setting up simulations within FEA software (Experience with SolidWorks, CATIA, OnShape, Autodesk Inventor, etc...) • Solid foundation in mechanics in general, with particular practical emphasis on solid mechanics and structural analysis. • Ability to connect FEA simulations with experimental results and validation. • Excellent communication and interpersonal skills; ability to explain technical concepts clearly to diverse student audiences. • Previous experience is an asset but less important than demonstrated practical FEA expertise.

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
duties: MIE311 is an elective course for 3rd year Mechanical Engineering students. The course builds upon the pre-requisite thermodynamics course, and focuses on cycles and applications. Topics include: Otto cycle, diesel cycle, Brayton cycle, Rankine cycle, cogeneration, vapour compression and absorption refrigeration, heat pump systems. TA DUTIES INCLUDE: - Supervision of heat engines laboratories (default in person, with online as required by instructor) - Demonstration of laboratory equipment (default in person, with online as required by instructor) - Updating lab manual - Composing lab report questions - Grading of formal lab reports - Composing assignment questions - Grading assignments & exams - Preparing and solving problem sets and draft exams - Midterm invigilation - Grading midterm exam questions - Updating grades spreadsheet and course website - Additional administrative support, meetings with instructor, and other duties as required
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicant must have taken MIE 411/311/303 or equivalent previously (application should provide year/term MIE 411/311/303 was taken; if equivalent course, please provide course description) REQUIREMENTS: 1. A large portion of the TA duties include leading experiments within the heat engines lab (MC120), including experiments, such as the IC engine, air compression, diesel engine, and gas turbine. Prior successful experience in the heat engines lab (as a TA or a student) would be an asset. 2. TAs must be available to supervise laboratories in person as well as online. Previous experiences leading tutorials, coaching sports teams, summer camps, etc. would be valuable experiences that would help you lead engaging labs. 3. Outstanding written and oral English communication is an essential requirement for all of these duties. Applicants must demonstrate strong evidence of their communication skills. 4. TAs must be available the entire term in person for administrative meetings, discussion of course materials, etc. 5. TAs must have the ability to move duties online. INSTRUCTIONS: In addition to the online application, please submit the following via email to Jason Chan: 1) a cover letter addressed to Jason Chan (jasonk.chan@mail.utoronto.ca) that makes a compelling and concise case for being selected as a TA for this course. (1 page max). 2) 1-page CV that highlights your teaching experience, 3) A 2 min (max) pre-recorded mini-lecture (video) to introduce the IC Engine Lab to students at the beginning of the lab (see attached IC Engine lab manual). 4) An example of your technical writing for which you were the sole author and editor. All items should be combined into a single PDF file, with the filename labelled as FirstName-LastName-MIE311-2026-TA-Applicant-DD-MM-YYYY.PDF, where DD (day), MM (month), and YYYY (year) reflect the day of application submission. The subject heading of your email should be "MIE311-2025 TA Applicant: FirstName Last Name" As the course instructor, I will rank the applicants, and the MIE administration will make the final decisions. MIE311 laboratory package: https://www.mie.utoronto.ca/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/MIE311_Lab_Manual_Compiled.pdf
salery: $53.92 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

department: Department of Mechanical and Industrial Engineering
duties: Organizational Design integrates various perspectives of organizational theory, including change, risk and project management, teamwork, and systems design. The course will be highly applied, drawing from industry examples and perspectives. The TAs will be valuable members of the teaching team. The course examines how engineers as managers can create more effective organizations. The Head TA will be charged with assisting the professor to proactively manage the course Quercus, respond to student messages, respond to unexpected issues and barriers, and oversee the three team TAs as tasks are assigned and completed. TA duties include: ASSISTING THE PROFESSOR Help construct tests, prepare materials, grade assignments, design lessons (if interested). Understand the objectives and learning goals the professor has set for the students so you can communicate course materials to them; know the professor"s expectations of you. GRADING PAPERS OR EXAMS Grade tests, exams, assignments. Understand the course content and be able to follow a student"s thinking to interpret answers that might not be complete; develop and hold tutorials for the assignments to help students understand what is required of them; be consistent so your grading is fair and reliable; know your department"s grading procedures and policies and work with your course supervisor to develop grading criteria; become familiar with your department"s and the University"s policies on academic integrity; develop strategies for dealing with unhappy students. Identify critical information from lectures or readings and then elaborate on it to help students understand the material; attend some class lectures or watch videos so you understand what the students need to know; in some cases, be responsible for testing and grading students" work.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Successful applicants will meet the following criteria: *A team player *Dependable, and detail oriented *Strong communication skills *Responsive (on Piazza and Slack) *Compassionate to students and excited about teaching and learning *Experience taking MIE459 ideal. *Current graduate student (MEng, MASc, PhD) in an engineering discipline at U of T *Work experience in industry, management or supervisory role ideal

department: Office of the Faculty Registrar, Faculty of Arts & Science
appointment_size:
•For exam shifts during the Special Deferred Exam Period:  You might be scheduled for a morning, afternoon, or evening exam any day between October 27-31, 2025 (as required based on the Deferred Exam Period schedules). 
•Depending on when you are scheduled, your shift might begin as early as 8:00am and/or end as late as 10:30pm.
•Most days will have multiple in-person exam shifts within one working day, and you might be required to work each day within this period.
•All in-person exams will take place on the St. George Campus.
duties:
•Responsibility for the confidentiality of final & deferred examinations
•Providing coordination and consistency in the administration of such final examinations, in accordance with the policies and procedures which have been or may be established by the Office of the Registrar
•Picking up exam materials before an exam
•Setting up the exam room by distributing question papers and exam materials
•Working collaboratively with the instructor/course representative to best facilitate the exam
•Ensuring Faculty policies on exam administration are followed
•Monitoring for academic misconduct and recording incidents when needed
•Making announcements to students in the exam room
•Collecting student signatures
•Potentially dealing with urgent situations such as students who are unexpectedly sick or fire alarms
•Completing required paperwork with accuracy and integrity
•You may be called to a meeting after the Final Exam Period to discuss any incidents that occurred during exams. You will be paid for this time.
positions: The number of CPOs employed by the Office of the Faculty Registrar is dependent upon  the number of in-person exam slots.
qualifications:
Experience with facilitating Faculty of Arts & Science final in-person examinations is an asset.
- Exceptional service and professionalism
- Reliable
- Excellent communication (both oral and written)
- Excellent problem-solving skills
- Ability to manage and resolve emergency, difficult or sensitive situations effectively using tact, diplomacy and good judgement
- Situational awareness and the ability to manage changing priorities
- Understanding and ability to apply relevant University and Faculty policies and procedures
- Excellent organizational skills
- Ability to effectively direct large groups
salery: This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement

application_procedure: To apply, please email your CV and contact info of two teaching references to unit1app@math.toronto.edu with the subject line "application for MAT235Y-SINIF".
duties: This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections.  The instructor will be a member of a coordinated team with a designated course coordinator.  Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs.  The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings. Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator, the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate.   Normally, classes and tutorials will be conducted synchronously online during the scheduled lecture and tutorial times, respectively. There should be no synchronous activities outside of the scheduled lecture and tutorial hours. Final Exam is expected to be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD program in 2020, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathematics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Recent previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course is an asset.

If you are applying for more than one position please send one email per job application package. The email subject line should contain your last name and the course code for which you are applying.

job_title: Coping with Complexity in Persistent Illness
application_procedure: This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement. Positions posted here are open to Graduate Students in the School of Graduate Studies and Postdoctoral Fellows. Preference in hiring shall be given to Graduate Students enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto or those who have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto. Visit the Lawrence Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing website for instructions on how to apply for Teaching Assistant positions https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/current-students/teaching-assistantships/. The University of Toronto is strongly committed to diversity within its community and especially welcomes applications from racialized persons / persons of colour, women, Indigenous / Aboriginal People of North America, persons with disabilities, LGBTQ2S+ persons, and others who may contribute to the further diversification of ideas. Candidates who are members of Indigenous, Black, racialized and LGBTQ2S+ communities, persons with disabilities, and other equity seeking groups are encouraged to apply, and their lived experience shall be taken into consideration as applicable to the position. The University strives to be an equitable and inclusive community, and proactively seeks to increase diversity among its community members. Our values regarding equity and diversity are linked with our unwavering commitment to excellence in the pursuit of our academic mission. The University is committed to the principles of the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA). As such, we strive to make our recruitment, assessment and selection processes as accessible as possible and provide accommodations as required for applicants with disabilities. If you require any accommodation at any point during the application and hiring process, please contact uoft.careers@utoronto.ca. During employment, to request accommodation from the University, contact the supervisor or department chair and/or Health & Wellbeing Programs & Services at hwb@utoronto.ca. For more information about accommodations at UofT, please visit our Accommodation webpage. Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located. Where the duties are intended to be performed at another location, such other location will be specified in the posting.
duties: In-Person teach in the skills lab - four hours per week; Complete independent preparation for lab teaching on a weekly basis; Meet with supervisor as required; Participate in course orientation and  meetings.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Masters or PhD students; Current UofT graduate students in good standing.
qualifications_preferred: Interest in teaching and working with novice nursing students; Clinical expertise and experience relevant to the specific course and clinical focus. CNO registration as an RN is preferred.

duties: On-campus classes with in-person tests/exams if possible; Meetings with supervisor; Course orientation, marking meetings and as per supervisor request; Reading text and journal articles relevant to course content and assignments; Marking, grading and providing feedback for assignments and papers (complete all grading for all student work that is completed during the term of the appointment, up to and including final exams); Monitoring and responding to Quercus postings and email enquiries from students; Meeting and providing support with students during TA & requested hours; Invigilating exam; assist with tabulation of grades; Attending lecture and learning settings as negotiated with supervisor.

qualifications_minimum: Masters or PhD students; Current UofT graduate students in good standing; interest in teaching and working with novice nursing students; Clinical expertise and experience relevant to the specific course and clinical focus; The hiring criteria for Teaching Assistant positions are academic qualifications, the need to acquire experience, previous experience and previous satisfactory employment under the provisions of this Collective Agreement.
qualifications_preferred: CNO registration as an RN is preferred.

application_procedure: 1. Also submit in PDF format a copy of your resume along with a note (email is fine) from your thesis supervisor indicating s/he is satisfied with your program progress and supports your application.
duties: 1.  Preparation and delivery of lectures in the course. 2.  Supervision of T.A(s) assigned to course. 3.  Preparation, supervision and grading of tests and examinations in accordance with University regulations as described in the Faculty of Arts & Science Academic Handbook. 4.  Providing scheduled office hours for academic counseling of students. 5. All or majority of duties are planned to be in-person, but they may also have online component.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Enrolment as full-time student in the Ph.D. program in Economics at the U of T
qualifications_preferred: Completion of all PhD course requirements including 2nd year paper preferred
salery: Rate of pay: Current rates as of January 1, 2026 - $9442.98 (per half course, excluding vacation pay). Course Instructors (first time CI’s) - effective January 1, 2026 - $10,553.15 (per half course, excluding vacation pay).  Please note that should rates stipulated in the collective agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the collective agreement shall prevail.

job_title: Foundations in Community Dis/Engagement and Solidarity Seminar
application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter, CV, and the contact information for two references in the same PDF document to typ.office@utoronto.ca by Tuesday, October 7, 2025  at 5 PM.
duties: Introduction to Critical Studies in Equity & Solidarity Studies (CSES) seminar (TYP051Y1) is  a prepatory course at the Transitional Year Programme (TYP). This course supports students enrolled in Introduction to Critical Studies in Equity & Solidarity (CSE240H1F)  and Foundations in Dis/Engagement and Solidarity (CSE270H1S). CSES is an interdisciplinary program that explores how social relations and practices of power and privilege are (re)produced locally and transnationally.  The course instructor will preparing a syllabus that align with the course content in CSE270H1S, consult/ meet with the instructor(s),  lead weekly seminars for TYP students (Fridays from 11 am - 1 pm), hold office hours, advise students and evaluate assignments, and manage the course Quercus. Additional duties will include attending CSE270H1S lectures and TYP meetings. Other duties will be determined in consultation with TYP's Director and  Registrar.  Please note, this course will be offered in person, with online administrative  elements (i.e. Quercus). For more information about TYP, please visit typ.utoronto.ca.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants must be  Graduate Students enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto or those who have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto. Preference will be given to applicants engaged in research in Critical Equity studies. Thorough understanding of CSE240H1 & CSE270H1 course content is required. Demonstrated commitment to equity and anti-oppressive/social-justice approaches to education. Teaching experience facilitating small groups and Familiarity with Quercus and online instructional methods is desirable.
qualifications_preferred: Previous teaching experience, and/or coursework familiar with historical and theoretical foundations of inequities. In-depth knowledge of Critical Equity studies course content. Knowledge of/experience with adult education and the University of Toronto Transitional Year Program or similar programming. Experience advising students and providing writing support in the social sciences and/ or humanities. Shortlisted candidates may be asked to complete a brief written screening question and/or an interview.
salery: In accordance with the current CUPE3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement, the Course Instructor rate of pay will be $9,442.98 excludes vacation pay for a half course

duties:
The TA will facilitate a weekly two-hour in-person tutorial of 7-36 students. The TA is expected to become actively involved with students who are working through a model design project. This includes working with student groups on team formation, brainstorming facilitation, team decision making, and writing during the tutorial sessions. The TA also marks a number of written assignments during the term. The TA is required to attend weekly teaching team meetings and benchmarking sessions prior to marking each assignment. After marking is completed, the TA is required to run assignment debriefing sessions during tutorials with the students when returning the marked assignments.
There are mandatory team meetings with the Course Coordinator and Communication Instructor. The meeting goal is to discuss how the tutorials went the previous week, what is planned for the following week, what is being covered in lectures, and discuss any problems that may have arisen.

Previous ESP course training could be considered an asset.

qualifications_minimum: Completed Master's Degree in Art History, with historical and geographical breadth of knowledge as relevant to the course material, and previous TA experience. Course description: An introduction to the arts and architecture from antiquity to the present day which emphasizes the deep connection between art and history. This broad overview will examine carefully a selection of works, including real objects and buildings in Toronto, which are representative of the upper-level courses currently offered by the Art History faculty. Special attention is paid to developing essential art historical skills, including the ability to look at, analyze, and write about works of art and architecture. Tutorials provide training in and experience applying the basic principles and vocabulary employed in art-historical scholarship. Frequent short writing assignments and exercises will be based on readings, lectures, and museum or gallery visits to collections in Toronto.
qualifications_preferred: Current PhD Candidate or Postdoctoral Fellow in Art History is preferred.

job_title: Art and Consumers in the Renaissance (1400-1700)
duties: Duties may include: attending weekly lectures (Tuesdays 3:00-5:00pm in person); grading, tabulating and tracking grades; invigilating tests and exams; holding office hours for regular meetings with students. Full duties to be determined by course instructor.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Background in Art History, with historical and geographical breadth of knowledge as relevant to the course material. Course description: It has long been said that the material culture of the Renaissance generated the first stir of consumerism with a variety of artifacts produced from 1400 to 1700 in Italy. This course explores the material culture of Renaissance consumerism and discusses the production and function of works in different art media.
qualifications_preferred: Current PhD Student or Postdoctoral Fellow in Art History is preferred.

job_title: An Introduction to Statistical Reasoning and Data Science
application_procedure:
Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. 
The deadline to submit your application is September 26, 2022. For more information, you may contact: Angela Niazmand, Undergraduate and TA Administrator, Department of Statistical Sciences, University of Toronto
700 University Ave- Rm 9160- 6, Ontario Power Building, Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5, www.statistics.utoronto.ca, E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca

If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact
jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3
duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated. Duties will include any or all of the following: attending lectures, running 
tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on on-line discussion boards, participating in training 
sessions, meeting with the instructors, holding office hours, grading student homework including written reports, and 
assisting with grading of tests and exams.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior undergraduate students (third and fourth year) with strong background in statistics and exemplary communication skills may also be considered.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate student with strong background in statistics, as well as excellent communication and writing skills, and the ability to interact well with undergraduate students.
